Very well put, RT. You are the antithesis of ideological feminism.

See why the countries deemed most equal, such as Sweden and Norway, are defunding gender ideology:
http://www.menshealthaustralia.net/content/nordic-countries-defund-gende...

Like most recent sermons on equality, this one sacrifices freedom and personal choice in favor of the blunt instrument of government, used to force "equality" on the populous.

In modern America, there is no secretive cabal that meets in men's clubs to conspiratorially conjure up new ways to suppress women's earnings and deny them advancement opportunities. Qualified females are hired at better rates than their male counterparts, promoted more rapidly, and highly sought after, given the corporate world's focus on gender equality. Often this approach actually backfires, as less qualified women are hired and promoted ahead of men in order to meet certain goals and metrics, leading to tokenism and incompetence.

As a society, we shouldn't force an equality of outcomes. Perceived gender inequalities are mostly the product of lifestyle choices, not to mention the unavoidable fact that only women can bear children or breastfeed them. If the vast majority of people who want to be auto mechanics are male, and those who want to be kindergarten teachers female, why is that inherently bad? Why must we have de facto gender quotas?

Furthermore, large expansions in entitlements to parents will lead to a backlash from employers and non-parents against them, as non-parents and employers are forced to support their lifestyle choices. Our planet, our society, and our labor force would all greatly benefit from more people choosing not to have children, rather than the converse.

What inherited advantage? What failure to make it possible for others to reach their potential? This is just more of that tired left-wing demagoguery.

I like some of the things you said, but in some instances, I believe you have the cart before the horse.

For exp.: "...feminized jobs are given low economic...value"

No. The jobs are advertised at a certain salary and mostly women apply for them because of tradition created out of the husband-as-provider expectation (or primary provider). Men, because they feel the pressure of the provider role and the need to earn a good wage, are "priced out" of low-paying jobs, including the "female" jobs you cite.

See: “The Doctrinaire Institute for Women's Policy Research: A Comprehensive Look at Gender Equality”
http://malemattersusa.wordpress.com/2012/02/16/the-doctrinaire-institute...

First, childcare is a job, whether it is done by a paid caregiver or a parent. If we do not consider full-time caregiving employment (from childcare to eldercare workers) we are solidifying money as the only important measure of cultural self-worth. That said, "mothering" is a term that should be disconnected to gender. Both men and women can and should be considered capable of the caregiving function (again, on both ends of the age spectrum). So the issue here is that caregiving is feminized and feminized jobs are given low economic and cultural value (see teachers, nurses, etc) so that even those who are employed are substantially underpaid. Then, if women continue to be socialized that caregiving and typically "feminized" professions are what they are best suited to from a very young age and they grow up to value those functions and earn substantially less or drop out of the workforce entirely, is anyone surprised? The only way to change the discussion is to start paying teachers and nurses and caregivers--all the traditionally "feminine" career paths--a living wage and raise their standard of living to a place where these professions will attract both men and women, while also recognizing that childcare is not a cop out but an actual, valid job. Then we can begin to have a conversation about how to make women equal in the workforce.

Until then, this is all just so much noise.

Wisdomtooth, it's true that there is a waiting list of candidates hoping for that unpaid internship. But your comment, "You don't want to work for nothing? Don't apply" is reminiscent of Marie Antoinette's "Let them eat cake".

The only people who can afford to do an unpaid internship are those whose parents are able and willing to support them. It may be "worth the connections and associations", but not everyone can afford to work for free. I admire Ms. Sandberg but in this matter she was wrong.

No the issue of childcare is not missing from the debate. it's mentioned here, but the writers leave out important details:

"Professors Blau and Kahn also noted, however, that these [family friendly] policies could backfire, encouraging “women who would have otherwise had a stronger labor force commitment to take part-time jobs or lower-level positions.” "

What they mean is, affordable daycare means women end up choosing lower pay positions that require them to work less hours, so they can spend more time with their children. Unaffordable daycare is one of the reason so many women try hard to climb the ladder and get promotions.

Then, the following quote "[family friendly policies] could encourage employer discrimination and “leave women less likely to be considered for high-level positions.”"

What he is talking about here is the fact that some job categories need to be filled by people who don't take family leave. You can't promote women to certain job positions requiring lots of responsibility, and then allow them to take family leave.

The problem could be solved by letting companies advertise some positions as motherhood friendly or not -- similar to how the American with Disabilities act requires employers "reasonably accomodate" disability, sex discrimination law could require employers to "reasonably accommodate" motherhood.

Basically, motherhood is incompatible with perfect workplace gender equality.

1. The questions could all be answered by a range of agreement or disagreement, from "very strongly" to "slightly." So the qualifiers were built into the choice of 9 possible answers.

2. I'd like to consider myself a reasonable person, but I found it very easy to agree or disagree totally with some of them, e.g., '18. A "woman's place" should be wherever she wants to be. The days when women are submissive to their husbands and social conventions belong strictly in the past.'

I think *no* reasonable person would insist on numerous qualifiers to express agreement with that statement. You think *any* reasonable person would. Maybe your idea of "reasonable" includes people who would have women at a lower level than men. My idea of "reasonable" sure doesn't.

All the test questions make such broad and unqualified generalizations that no reasonable person can agree or disagree with any of them. Any reasonable person would insert numerous qualifiers before expressing either agreement or disagreement.

P.S. The Boston Tea Party was the vandalism and destruction of private property. It was the opposite of anything a conservative would value.

Thanks for the 25 "recommend" votes. To answer my critics, I understand that the Republicans are a ball and chain around the President's leg and that their control of the House makes things much more difficult. I also understand that even when the Democrats controlled both houses of Congress, many, such as the Blue Dog Democrats, disfavored parts of the President's agenda, so life was not a cakewalk then either.

That said—and no, I don't hate the President and would like to see him succeed—he's taken surprisingly little advantage of the prerogatives vested in him to act unilaterally (admittedly, the recent presidential Dream Act promulgation shows that he can do this) and often seems disengaged when substance is required to follow oratory. (I have this mental image of him golfing when he could be schmoozing with legislators.) He's said so much for so often with so little action following it that I think anyone would be foolish to rely on his silvery rhetoric. I don't, but if others want to, be my guest. Just prepare yourself for regular disappointment.

To quote the article:

"The president spoke immediately after Brazil’s president, Dilma Rousseff, delivered a blistering denunciation of the United States over reports that the National Security Agency monitored e-mails, text messages and other electronic communications between Ms. Rousseff and her aides. . . .

"Mr. Obama took note of these grievances, saying the United States was rethinking its surveillance activities . . . . 'we have begun to review the way that we gather intelligence, so as to properly balance the legitimate security concerns of our citizens and allies with the privacy concerns that all people share.' ”

I wish I could believe this, but I have to file it in the thick folder of nice statements that President Obama has made over the years that lead to no change. He talks about fixing income inequality too, but hasn't put the weight of the presidency behind any practical proposals. (How about a $15/hour minimum wage?) He talks about social justice but has, according to Reason magazine, pardoned only a single low-level drug offender, while probably hundreds of thousands languish in prison for trivial drug possession and sale offenses. He was for same-sex marriage, then against it, then for it . . . I'm losing track of how often he pronounced himself on one side or another regarding that issue. I cannot take seriously most of what he says. Too often either nothing comes of it or he's saying the opposite a month later.

At last, we have an American president who is pragmatic and realistic in his approach to global issues. It is high time we realize that we don't have that kind of clout we used to have in the cold war era. Mindless war mongering would only lead to more wars. The business of fostering world peace is the UN's business and not an American or Russian business. Peace is a matter of co-operation among nations and not one of  thrusting of any one nation's opinion on others. Even if america undertakes the responsibility of global policing singly, such a position is untenable and cannot be maintained for long. But it is eye-opening to realize that no nation has that sort of goodwill that was enjoyed in the cold war days and the world is rendered effectively leaderless. It makes us wonder if the world is teetering on the brink of chaos.

Could it be that Israel is not threat to all those nations?
